explicatoryContent.conceptExplanation:
Energy is the capacity to do work or cause change. It exists in many forms and is constantly transforming. Kinetic energy is the energy of motion—the faster and heavier an object, the more kinetic energy it has. Potential energy is stored energy waiting to be used. Gravitational potential energy depends on height, elastic potential energy is in stretched materials, and chemical potential energy is stored in molecular bonds.

Energy transforms constantly. In a roller-coaster, gravitational potential at the top becomes kinetic energy as the cart speeds down, then back to potential as it climbs. A Newton's cradle shows similar transformations. In all cases, the total energy stays the same, but some becomes heat through friction.

Heat transfers through three mechanisms: conduction (through direct contact), convection (through moving fluids like air or water), and radiation (through electromagnetic waves like sunlight).

No machine is 100% efficient because some energy always becomes dispersed thermal energy. Sankey diagrams help visualise this—arrow widths show how much energy flows where, making efficiency easy to see.

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples developed sophisticated fire-starting methods that transform kinetic energy to thermal energy through friction. The fire drill, fire plough, fire saw, and percussion methods each demonstrate deep understanding of energy transformation.

As it descends, potential transforms to kinetic energy—the cart speeds up. Climbing the next hill, kinetic becomes potential again. Each hill is slightly lower because energy is lost to friction with the tracks and air, becoming heat and sound.

relational.modelResponse: Lifting one ball gives it gravitational potential energy. When released, this becomes kinetic energy as it swings down. explicatoryContent.introduction: Energy is what makes things happen all around us. From the moment you wake up to when you go to sleep, energy is constantly changing from one form to another. Understanding these changes helps us understand how everything in the physical world works.
keyPoints: Energy comes in different forms including thermal (heat), kinetic (movement), gravitational potential (height), elastic potential (stretched objects), and chemical (stored in bonds)
Energy can be classified as either kinetic (motion) or potential (stored)
Energy transforms from one type to another but is never created or destroyed
Heat transfers through conduction (contact), convection (fluid movement), and radiation (waves)
Some energy always becomes heat during transformations, limiting efficiency
Sankey diagrams show energy flows with arrow widths representing energy amounts

vocabulary.definition: Energy associated with motion, expressed as KE = ½mv² for translational motion. Distinguished from thermal energy, which represents disordered kinetic motion at the molecular level.

Energy stored in configurations of matter and fields. Gravitational potential energy (PE = mgh for near-Earth) depends on position in gravitational field. Elastic and chemical PE represent energy stored in atomic configurations.
The conversion of energy between forms, constrained by the first law of thermodynamics (conservation) and the second law (entropy increase, limiting efficiency).
The ratio of useful energy output to total energy input. For thermal systems, Carnot efficiency (η = 1 - Tc/Th) represents the theoretical maximum.
A quantitative visualisation of energy flows where arrow widths are proportional to energy quantities. Essential for identifying losses, calculating efficiency, and comparing system designs.

analogies.analogy: A roller-coaster is like a bank account for energy. At the top, you have savings (potential energy). Going down, you spend savings on speed (kinetic energy). Going up, you save again, but friction means you can never save quite as much.
analogies.explanation: This helps visualise how energy changes form and why some is always lost.

explicatoryContent.conceptExplanation:
Energy is the capacity to do work or cause change. It exists in many forms and is constantly transforming. Kinetic energy is the energy of motion—the faster and heavier an object, the more kinetic energy it has. Potential energy is stored energy waiting to be used. Gravitational potential energy depends on height, elastic potential energy is in stretched materials, and chemical potential energy is stored in molecular bonds.

Energy transforms constantly. In a roller-coaster, gravitational potential at the top becomes kinetic energy as the cart speeds down, then back to potential as it climbs. A Newton's cradle shows similar transformations. In all cases, the total energy stays the same, but some becomes heat through friction.

Heat transfers through three mechanisms: conduction (through direct contact), convection (through moving fluids like air or water), and radiation (through electromagnetic waves like sunlight).

No machine is 100% efficient because some energy always becomes dispersed thermal energy. Sankey diagrams help visualise this—arrow widths show how much energy flows where, making efficiency easy to see.

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples developed sophisticated fire-starting methods that transform kinetic energy to thermal energy through friction. The fire drill, fire plough, fire saw, and percussion methods each demonstrate deep understanding of energy transformation.

caseStudy.title: Energy at Luna Park Melbourne
caseStudy.scenario: The Scenic Railway at Luna Park Melbourne demonstrates energy transformations. A motor lifts the cart to the first peak, giving it gravitational potential energy. As it descends, potential transforms to kinetic energy—the cart speeds up. Climbing the next hill, kinetic becomes potential again. Each hill is slightly lower because energy is lost to friction with the tracks and air, becoming heat and sound.
caseStudy.elaborationSource: Elaboration 1: Investigating kinetic and potential energy in roller-coasters; Elaboration 6: Comparing energy changes in physical events
observations: The cart slows climbing hills and speeds up descending
Each successive hill is slightly lower due to energy losses
The brakes get warm, showing where kinetic energy goes at the end
You can hear the cart on the tracks—sound is energy leaving the system
questions: Why does the roller-coaster only need a motor for the first hill?
What would happen if there was no friction?
Where does all the energy go by the end of the ride?
caseStudy.realWorldConnection: Understanding energy transformations helps engineers design safer, more efficient rides. It also explains why we need to keep putting energy into systems—cars need fuel because they continuously lose energy to friction.

strengths: Roller-coasters clearly show potential and kinetic energy interchange
Energy changes are visible and felt by riders
Decreasing hill heights directly show energy loss

remember.stem: Which type of energy does a moving car have?

options.text: Kinetic energy
options.feedback: Correct! Kinetic energy is the energy of movement. A moving car has kinetic energy.

options.text: Elastic energy
options.feedback: Not quite. Elastic energy is stored in stretched or squashed objects. A moving car has kinetic energy.

options.text: Chemical energy
options.feedback: Not quite. Chemical energy is stored in the fuel, not in the movement.
options.misconception: Confusing energy source with motion energy

options.text: Nuclear energy
options.feedback: Not quite. Nuclear energy comes from atoms. A normal moving car has kinetic energy.

remember.stem: What are the three ways that heat energy can transfer from one place to another?

options.text: Burning, melting, and freezing
options.feedback: Not quite. These involve heat but are not transfer methods. The three ways are conduction, convection, and radiation.

options.text: Conduction, convection, and radiation
options.feedback: Correct! Heat transfers by conduction (through contact), convection (through moving fluids), and radiation (through waves).

options.text: Kinetic, potential, and thermal
options.feedback: Not quite. These are types of energy, not transfer methods.
options.misconception: Confusing energy types with transfer methods

options.text: Evaporation, condensation, and precipitation
options.feedback: Not quite. These are parts of the water cycle, not heat transfer methods.
options.misconception: Confusing water cycle with heat transfer

understand.stem: Why does a light bulb get hot when it is on?

options.text: Because it makes too much light
options.feedback: Not quite. The bulb gets hot because some electrical energy transforms into heat, not because of excess light.

options.text: Because the electricity is too hot when it enters
options.feedback: Not quite. Electricity is not hot. Heat is produced when electrical energy transforms inside the bulb.

options.text: Because some electrical energy transforms into heat energy as well as light
options.feedback: Correct! Energy transformation in bulbs produces both light and heat. This is why bulbs get warm.

options.text: Because the bulb absorbs heat from the room
options.feedback: Not quite. The bulb produces heat internally; it does not absorb room heat.

understand.stem: In a Sankey diagram, what does the width of an arrow represent?

options.text: The speed at which energy flows
options.feedback: Not quite. Arrow width shows quantity of energy, not speed of flow.

options.text: The temperature of the energy
options.feedback: Not quite. Sankey diagrams show energy quantity, not temperature.

options.text: The type of energy being transferred
options.feedback: Not quite. Energy type is usually shown by labels. Width shows quantity.

options.text: The quantity of energy flowing along that pathway
options.feedback: Correct! Wider arrows mean more energy flows along that path.

apply.stem: On a roller-coaster, at which point does the cart have the most gravitational potential energy?

options.text: At the bottom of the biggest drop
options.feedback: Not quite. At the bottom, the cart is lowest so has least potential energy. It has maximum kinetic energy there.

options.text: Where the cart is moving fastest
options.feedback: Not quite. Maximum speed means maximum kinetic energy, not potential energy.

options.text: At the highest point of the track
options.feedback: Correct! Gravitational potential energy depends on height. Higher position means more potential energy.

options.text: Just before the cart stops at the end
options.feedback: Not quite. At the end, most energy has become heat through friction. Maximum potential is at the highest point.

apply.stem: A phone charger is 85% efficient. If it uses 10 joules of electrical energy, how much is converted to heat?

options.text: 0.85 joules
options.feedback: Not quite. 85% is the useful output. Heat wasted is 15%, which is 1.5 joules.

options.text: 8.5 joules
options.feedback: Not quite. 8.5 joules is the useful output (85%). The heat is the remaining 1.5 joules (15%).

options.text: 10 joules
options.feedback: Not quite. If all became heat, efficiency would be 0%. At 85% efficiency, only 1.5 joules becomes heat.

options.text: 1.5 joules
options.feedback: Correct! 85% efficiency means 15% is wasted as heat. 15% of 10 joules = 1.5 joules.

analyse.stem: A Rube Goldberg machine uses many steps to do a simple task. At each step, some energy is lost as heat. What does this mean for overall efficiency?

options.text: The machine gets more efficient because it has more steps
options.feedback: Not quite. More steps mean more chances for energy loss. Each step reduces overall efficiency.
options.misconception: Thinking more steps means better efficiency

options.text: The efficiency stays the same because energy is conserved
options.feedback: Not quite. While total energy is conserved, more becomes unusable heat at each step.

options.text: The efficiency depends on which type of energy is being transformed
options.feedback: Not quite. Regardless of energy types, each step loses some energy, reducing overall efficiency.

options.text: Overall efficiency is lower because energy is lost at every step
options.feedback: Correct! Each step loses energy as heat. With many steps, these losses add up, reducing overall efficiency.

analyse.stem: Why do the hills on a roller-coaster get smaller after the first big drop?

options.text: To make the ride less scary for passengers
options.feedback: Not quite. The physics reason is energy loss. The cart cannot climb as high because energy is lost to friction.
options.misconception: Focusing on design intent rather than physics

options.text: Because the cart loses energy to friction and sound at each hill
options.feedback: Correct! Energy is lost to friction and sound at each hill, so the cart has less energy for subsequent climbs.

options.text: Because gravity gets stronger as the ride goes on
options.feedback: Not quite. Gravity stays constant. The decreasing hills reflect energy loss.

options.text: Because the cart speeds up and uses more energy
options.feedback: Not quite. The cart does not use energy to speed up. Energy is lost to friction, not to motion.

evaluate.stem: A student claims that Aboriginal fire drill methods are less scientific than using matches. Based on energy science, which evaluation is correct?

options.text: The student is correct because matches are modern technology
options.feedback: Not quite. Both methods use scientific principles. Being older does not make something less scientific.

options.text: The student is incorrect because both transform kinetic energy to thermal energy
options.feedback: Correct! Both methods transform energy according to the same physics principles. Aboriginal methods show deep understanding.

options.text: The student is correct because friction is not a real energy transformation
options.feedback: Not quite. Friction is definitely a real energy transformation mechanism.

options.text: The student is incorrect because Aboriginal methods produce more heat
options.feedback: Not quite. The amount of heat is not what makes something scientific. Both apply the same principles.

create.stem: You want to design a toy that shows energy transformations. Which design would best show kinetic, potential, and thermal energy?

options.text: A ball that rolls down a ramp, bounces on a trampoline, and lands on a heat-sensitive pad that changes colour
options.feedback: Correct! This shows kinetic (rolling), potential (on ramp and bouncing), and thermal energy (heat changing the pad's colour).

options.text: A battery-powered car that drives in circles
options.feedback: This shows chemical and kinetic energy, but potential and thermal transformations are less visible.
options.misconception: Not considering all three energy types

options.text: A simple light bulb connected to a battery
options.feedback: This shows electrical, light, and thermal energy, but not kinetic or gravitational potential energy clearly.

options.text: A stretched rubber band that is released
options.feedback: This shows elastic potential and kinetic energy, but thermal energy is not clearly demonstrated.
